reviews.review_text: A dramatic shift from the first game, 'American Nightmare' pushes the franchise more towards the action/shooter genre than the survival/horror of its first iteration. with plentiful reloads and ammo pick-ups, resource management is never a concern, which is fortunate as enemies are never in short supply either. The game still boasts impressive graphics, although the entire adventure is spread across only three maps, which you will frequently revisit. However, rather than feeling repetitive, each time you return to a map there are new challenges and I quickly came to appreciate the lessons I had learned from my last visit. The story is more fantastic and, at least in my opinion, slightly creepier thanks to the addition of new character (and Alan Wake's evil doppleganger) Mr. Scratch. The first game lacked an identifiable personification of evil with whom the player could relate (and hate); Mr Scratch fulfills that need very well. The adventure is fairly short but enjoyable throughout.

This is a pretty big departure from the original Alan Wake, but i don't really see the hate towards this that some people have. If you approach this like this should be approached, by considering this a shooter you will have fun. Gone are the good storyline (although there are some fun bits in this one), suspense, atmosphere and detailed locations of the original, this is a shooting fest for few hours set in the same world, and expanding the lore/plot of the original.  The combat itself is fluid, they seemed to concentrate on that mostly, which is understandable, but still the levels feel very empty. They're small and not crafted with the same passion that we had before. Basically they're just there to house some dudes in for you to shoot. The timeloop aspect of the plot, gives us some funny moments and pieces of dialoque, but it also makes running the levels a bit tedious.  Manuscript pages are back, and this time they're used to unlock weapons :D I don't know is that a good thing or not when thinking about how important part they were in on the last game, where we didn't really have much combat at all, but at least it's somehow funny when you look at it. And guns are plenty, but the bad guys come in shamefully low numbers for us who have accustomed to shooters. Game does offer arcade mode also so we aren't limited only to the campaign, but it's 10 minutes per level. If you want to shoot hordes of Taken, better be fast!  This is fun for a few hours, but this goes in the same category as Elder scrolls online vs Skyrim. People marched into ESO thinking it's the new skyrim because it had the same name. Yes, you play as Alan here, but he's ♥♥♥♥♥♥, he's had enough of this darkness nonsense, and he has the firepower to back his frustration!

With independent additions happens that they are often quite different than what after the contact with the basic version players expect. Wake's journey gets less creepy and more shooty in the fun but still somehow manages to be entertaining.

Great game! 9/10  I bought this game on sale for $2.99 and didn't expect much. I played the first game and loved it so I couldn't pass this one up. I am so glad I didn't pass it up, it is worth buying even if it is not on sale!  While this game is not nearly as long as the original, the story will draw you in. I had a hard time putting the game down once I began playing the story mode. It is similiar to the originial in that there are manuscripts to collect, radio shows to listen to and also T.V. recordings to watch. You will also see some familiar characters.  The combat system is so very fluid! The combat in this game is addicting in itself and outside of the story there is plenty of arcade levels to enjoy the combat! The mechanics are nearly the same as the original but there are tons of weapons to find and unlock in this game! There are also several new enemies that were not in the original, each which requires a different tactic to take down effectively. And that brings me to my last highlight of the game..  Mr. Scratch! After seeing him in this game he is now my favorite villain of all time. He is so different from anything else I have seen in a game and he is definitely the biggest highlight of the game. The actor that plays him(and Alan Wake himself) is phenomenal!!   I can not wait for another sequel!

Alan Wake's American Nightmare is a fun game. But compared to its predecessor, it is definitely not as good. It doesn't live up to the first Alan Wake, mainly because they didn't put as much effort into it.  On the good side of things, Alan Wake's American Nightmare presents a brand new story that is very interesting, but it is a bit of a stretch from the first game. The weapon system is fun, making you collect manuscript pages to unlock new guns. The enemies are also new, improving on the plain minions from the previous installments. They introduce an all new Arcade Mode as well, and it provides entertainment for those that have finished the Main Story. Plus the game improves on the graphics, looking better than ever.  But, there are some bad things. The story is extremely short, especially taking into account you go to the same areas 3 times. Yes, it is a part of the story, but they should've considered making it more interesting. Increasing the difficulty each time isn't going to win you Game of the Year. The story in itself gets pretty boring. Fans of Alan Wake will enjoy it more, but it just doesn't pull you in. It doesn't do very much to keep your interest, relying on the gamer to finish the game just because they paid money for it, and they should get their money's worth. The new characters (everyone except Alan) are not that enticing either; they don't make you sympathize/get attached to them. And finally, the game is easy. I beat the game in three hours. That's just unprofessional.  It may sound like I hate the game, but I don't. The story is an episode of Night Springs that Alan wrote, putting Mr. Wake in a time loop set by his dark side. Alan must perfect everything in order to defeat his evil self, or be sent back in time to relive the defeat all over again, until he suceeds. The ending is decent, and it isn't that bad of a story overall. But it fails to make an impression that rivals the previous game or any other best seller. There is some replay value, but not much. The Arcade Mode is pretty much the only reason to go back to the game.  In summary, this game is for fans of Alan Wake. So make sure you've played that one first. The game has an okay story, but some great improvement, like new enemies and better graphics, but it just isn't as good as the first.  Score: 7/10 - Good

The sequel offers a satisfying conclusion to the story, but it has lost most of its predecessor's horror charm by giving the player fully automatic weapons and unlimited ammo/battery resupply. It sports a few new enemy types, which is refreshing, and a new GUI with a compass that actually shows where north is, which is nice. Being a quarter as long as the original, though, it is a tough sale - grab it when it's discounted if you liked the first game.

From reading about this game online, I got the impression that this wasn't directly related to the first game, and was in fact non-canon; an alternate timeline from the first game, possibly even a prequel.  It isn't.  What it is, is a totally awesome direct sequel of the first game. If you liked the original Alan Wake then you've got to play this one as well. It continues on the same plot from the first game, and brings it through to a satisfying conclusion (one which many felt the original game lacked). If the base game of Alan Wake is part one, then the DLC for the original game, combined American Nightmare, is part two.  It took me about 6 hours to complete, according to Steam, so bear that in mind when you're looking to buy it.  It's just as satisfying and fun as the first game, with some new enemies and a different environment format. Instead of the more linear style of the first game, this one gives you three open-world areas to explore and complete tasks in. They aren't huge, but they don't feel small, and I think any bigger would make them a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ to traverse.  American Nightmare is a must-play for fans of the original. However if you haven't played the first one, don't even touch this American Nightmare until you have,

And there is an ARCADE-MODE where you fight the shadow people on places like a an old western cemetery, and old western ghost towns ---> THIS IS EXTREMLY COOL! The story-mode is over fast, but the arcade-mode is worth playing again and again and always fun.   5 / 10 Story 10 / 10 Graphics and Scenery 10 / 10 Atmosphere 10 / 10 Gamplay 10 / 10 for the ARCADE-MODE

To start with, I really enjoyed the original Alan Wake. The setting, the writing, the mechanics, all good.  In some ways, this game is more of the same. Burn away darkness, blow away zom-.. sorry, 'Taken'.  But where Alan Wake's combat got pretty samey a few chapters in, American Nightmare's combat got samey almost immediately, and although Wake is supposed to be experienced at this sort of thing now, there was basically no tension. There were quite a few 'Oh crap' moments in the first game where the game would have a genuine surprise ready to throw at me. Not so in Nightmare.  The story (though I will not spoil) is also pretty light-weight. The big bad shows up to taunt you, throws some mooks at you, rinse and repeat. The nature of the Wakeverse is such that ambiguity about what's going on is entirely appropriate, but in Nightmare the writers seemed to use it as an excuse to avoid writing.  Buy Alan Wake, but you can readily give this one a pass.

I owned and played the full length game on the 360 and I ahve to say this DLC version is superior by far. Hop in, stomp some darkness and rock on!    Note: This is not a full-length game, as it was made to be an add-on to the original, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is it fun while it lasts.

If you haven't played Alan Wake, you might actually enjoy this, but won't really understand what's happening plot-wise, if you have played Alan Wake, you should definitely pick this up because it fixes a lot of the mechanics from the main game and adds more to the Alan Wake storyline.  This was released as DLC to the main game but it works as a stand alone title, and I believe it was originally meant to be a complete sequel but they only got funded for this size project.  If you enjoyed Alan Wake, but disliked the flashlight and shooting mechanics, you'll really appreciate this as the gunplay and combat is vastly improved. The enemy types are similar to the last game, and although they follow the same formula of flashlight-stun-shoot they have different abilities and appearances.  This game is set in the Arizona desert as opposed to the last games lush Pacific Northwest forests. The setting makes for a nice change of pace, and the big open landscape is really beneficial to the combat and exploration in my opinion. Also, whereas the last game took a lot of cues from American horror literature... and Twin Peaks. This game takes more cues from American horror films, and television, specifically the Twilight Zone, and it's very well off for it.  The story doesn't do as much as I would like in continuing the storyline from the first game but is still fairly interesting on it's own as it gives glimpses into what's going on in 'the real world.' I think the developers wanted to do more in that regard, but held back because they're still hoping to do a proper sequel at some point.  Finally, I'm not sure if it's because of the restraints on the development or just a design choice but the biggest drawback of the game is the constant backtracking. You replay each area at least three times due to a weird time travel element in the storyline. Although it does get sped up each time due to you changing things in the past it's still fairly annoying, I would have preferred more areas, or just a shorter experience honestly.  Overall though, the game is a good indication of the potential of the Alan Wake franchise in my opinion. I hope eventually a Publisher takes note of American Nightmare and decides to fund an actual Alan Wake 2 at some point.

Its sort of a little adjunct story to the main Alan Wake tale. They fix some of the nagging combat issues from the main game with a hammer called uzi, and that can be kind of fun... but... its one of those tradeoffs where there may be plenty of survival, but is there really that much horror when you have assault rifles and mag fed 9mm pistols etc? There was something (albeit admittedly something frustrating) to be said for the tension of frantically hand loading individual revolver rounds as the shadows closed in on you.  Where as the main game you slogged through the combat for the story, this almost takes the opposite approach... they spice up the combat but the story is a little less... riveting. Its not terrible, its just not going to live up to the main game there.   All in all its a decent little diversion for Alan Wake fans, but I wouldn't chalk it up as a must play.  (7/10)

American Nightmare provides players with a glimpse into the events that take place after the ending of the previous Alan Wake game. Alan Wake's American Nightmare brings you to a place where he is trapped inside a story that he wrote from he's own novel. Now he is the main actor of the story and he has a doppelganger that has been causing trouble around the place inside the novel. As the champion of light himself Alan Wake, he has to stop the trouble that his doppelganger is causing and find his wife to end the story with a happy ending. Overall I personally will give this game 8.5/10 because the story line is interesting and the gameplay is awsome. The combat style is quite unique compared to other 3rd person survival horror games and I really enjoyed it. Plus there are many various weapons you can choose which 2 of my favourites are the bowgun and the sniper rifle. I really recommend this game to whoever loves survivor horror games :)

I was looking forward to the Arizona night atmosphere and using Night Springs to tell the story but even that was very lackluster and squandered potential. The whole game is just way too easy, you can refill all your batteries and ammo to maximum all the time and most of the unlockable weapons weren't worth exploring the area to find the pages to unlock them with in the first place.  The first game suffered from being repetitive and what do they do this time? Make it even more repetitive by making you play the game three times. Combat is a little tighter thanks to having automatic weapons and limitless ammo strewn about all the time but that dissolves what little tension there is. As a big fan of the first game I can not recommend this to anyone, but rather just watch the cut scenes on youtube because the rest of the game is just shooting fish in a barrel with an assault rifle with a bottomless magazine.

I've read some negative reviews about American Nightmare and after playing for a few hours, it has surpassed all expectations. True, it's a lot less subtle horror compared to the first game but it still kept to the storyline. It shows the aftermath of the first Alan Wake. And while it may not be to everyone's tastes, I feel it's a lot more like a casual action-horror game with superb storytelling.  The music isn't as amazing as the first but there are a lot of throwbacks to the characters from the first game that I can forgive it. This one also has a lot more variety to enemies and weapons, which makes for an interesting playthrough.  Addendum: I finished this game in 6 hours so the gameplay is on the short side. Buying it while it's on sale might be more worth it for some people. It does come with a lot of arcade modes though.

It would be hard for me to talk about American Nightmare without touching on the original Alan Wake, because it very much feels like DLC that got spun into its own game. Alan Wake's strengths were its story, pacing, and graphics. The combat was a bit of a toss-up between decent and monotonous, depending on who you asked. American Nightmare is a shorter, weirder story told across three mostly open areas that you visit multiple times. The visuals are still sharp, but lose a lot of the atmosphere that Alan Wake had... the open desert just doesn't have the same creep factor as the dark woods, at least not as it's shown here. Dialogue is pretty snappy and clever, but it's propping up a story that really adds nothing to the themes introduced in Alan Wake.  So the main draw is the combat, and to its credit, it's a little more interesting than in Alan Wake. Enemy encounters are varied in makeup, and there are some new foes like ones that split if you shine light on them and creepy jumping spider things. All the original weapons are here, along with new additions like a nailgun, uzi, and carbine. You can unlock weapon cases with additional weapons by finding manuscript pages scattered around which encourages exploration, but honestly as large as the areas are, there's not much to find. Enemies only appear as you follow the main plot, and the game showers you with ammo and flare, more than enough to handle any situation. I tried playing on the harder of the two difficulties and the battles were still a breeze with all the resources I had, but I could be killed in just two hits which led to some frustration with unlucky hits at the ends of long fights.  There's an arcade mode similar to the mercenaries modes in Resident Evil that's pretty fun, assuming you like the combat. And that's really what American Nightmare boils down to, did you like the combat in Alan Wake? If so, this is for you, but don't come looking for the atmosphere or story of the original.

Alan Wake:American Nightmare is a spin-off to original game.You play as Alan Wake who is a writer and you must fight your way through darkness using light and firearms. While it’s not a direct sequel to previous game it still has same mechanics. But this time Remedy added more weapons making game more intense. While the main story is only 4 hours long it lacks good plot, and memorable characters. Not as good as the first game.  The action elements are tigher and more satisfying, but the game feels rushed and low budget. The single player campaign has very few unique locations and has you doing what feels like a lot of backtracking to fill out for time. The story doesn't even add that much to the original game, I sort of feel like it even subtracts from it.  It has some special moments, including pretty much any of the videos of Mr. Scratch you can find in the game, but overall is really not a great buy.  Perhaps a lot more special if you can get friends together for the online co-op, but given that Alan Wake is already fairly niche, that seems like a daunting task at best.  I highly recommend the original game, but American Nightmare gets a pass.

I actually liked this more than the regular campaign. This is kind of like a mix between the main campaign and a really basic open-world game.   It's a lot more open than the main campaign, but it's still rather linear, in that there is only ever one objective that can be done at a time, but you can roam around and explore. The areas aren't very big, and you can't freely travel between them, but this kind of gives me a taste of what the main campaign could have been like if it were designed as an open world game instead of being as utterly claustrophobic as it was.  This standalone DLC made quite a few changes from the original game, but not all of them were good. In the original Alan Wake, there were 4 weapons. In this one, there are 2 pistols, 2 rifles, 3 shotguns, 2 automatic weapons, a flaregun, and a nailgun. While choice is always good, some of the weapons are insanely overpowered, and some are just pointless. It seems like the developers took people's complaints about the main game's combat system to mean that combat was too difficult (it wasn't), and made it easier. Unfortunately, that means combat is now a cakewalk. Ammo is RIDICULOUSLY plentiful, weapons are insanely powerful, and enemies will barely ever even get close enough to hit you. Throughout the whole game, I got hit maybe 4 times, used 1 handheld flare, never fired the flaregun, and totally forgot I even HAD flashbangs.  They beefed up the flashlight as well. The enemies seem like they take less light to burn away the darkness, and the flashlight recharges CRAZY fast. From completely empty, it will charge to full in about 3 seconds, including the 1-2 second delay before it even starts charging. I was playing on Normal (there's only normal and nightmare), too, but maybe in this game that's the equivalent of easy.  The story is still rather interesting in this expansion, but the writing and voice acting are HORRIBLE. I mean absurdly stupid at times. I'm all for campy fun, but sometimes it gets so ridiculous that it really pulls you out of the experience. Speaking of acting, the little 'TV' segments where your dark self talks to you go on WAY too long sometimes, and don't really play any importance in how the game unfolds (and you don't get any achievements for them or anything).  Overall I liked this. For those of you who played and enjoyed the first Alan Wake game, come into this one with an open mind. As far as tone goes, this game couldn't be more different, replacing the elements of a mysterious thiller with the atmosphere of a pulp supernatural action flick.  This isn't really a bad thing, though. While less of a sequel than a low-budget side-story, the series still enjoys playing with the pacing of a level, giving you brief periods of exploration before attacking you at your more vulnerable moments. This is damged somewhat by the re-use of levels in the game, but the justification for this and the different approaches taken each time you revisit an area is very well done.  Where this game shines the most, however, is the story. Alan is trapped in Night Springs, the Twiligh Zone-esque show he created early in his career. While the previous predecesor explained his ability to change reality through writing only gave him the briefest glimmers of hope, this rendition allows gamers to experience a writer's power trip, one that allows Alan to quite literally rock the heavens after some careful planning and skill.  A special mention must also be given to the game's villian, Mr. Scratch. While the idea of an evil twin is a bit of a cliche, Mr. Scratch's showboating in everything he does is consistently entertaining. Few times has a villian been so intriguing just through sheer personality and charisma.

Episodic gaming is hardly a new concept. From Half-Life 2: Episode 1 to Sam & Max Save The World and SiN Episodes, there were many attempts at this format. Alan Wake's American Nightmare is different. Despite being a direct sequel to the original game, it is essentially a self-contained story with a beginning and a satisfying ending. In terms of quality, American Nightmare matches and occasionally surpasses the original. The combat has been improved (there is even an alternative aiming mode offered in the configurations menu); the improved overall feedback as well as the expanded arsenal and creative new foes make the 'fight with light' combat especially enjoyable. The story is the hightlight of American Nightmare, taking full advantage of the episodic format with its clever twist. The dialogue is snappy and frequently genuinely funny. The main antagonist, Mr. Scratch (or Mr. [...] if you prefer), is disturbing and hilarious, often both at once. I am running out of space here. Play it!

Don't get this expecting a full game. It's roughly a DLC, but the intro to the story is bundled in with the main game (the two Special episodes), so it gains an Arcade mode to add a bit of substance. A word of warning: for about the first third of the game, I was worried that it was utterly, inexplicably terrible. Luckily, it's not. It is, though, mediocre, a bit tedious, and lacks the charm and depth of the original.  The quickest way to explain it, in my mind, is that it feels like it was made by a different group with different priorities. Manuscript pages now unlock weapons, for no particularly well-defined reason. Ammo caches are scattered around the map, but this leads to some oddly low caps for items (5 flares, 5 flashbangs, 10 batteries). There's a bit more of an open-world feel, but the areas are small (you don't get a map, and realistically don't need one) and it leads to a lot of ugly invisible walls. There's a nice variety of new enemies, but generic enemies are basically all you fight (no 'boss battles' and just a few poltergeists). The villain is a fairly interesting character, but it feels like he doesn't really get his chance to shine (er, no pun intended - his TV bits are reasonably well done but his short appearances ingame are underwhelming).  Now, most of these are tradeoffs - there's plenty that's different, but it's not objectively worse. The real problem, as far as I'm concerned, is that the story and the overall flow of the game - which are pretty directly connected - just don't work this time around, certainly not in the way that they did so well in the original.  The entire game takes place in three areas, each of which has a living population of precisely one attractive woman, which considering that in theory Wake is doing all the writing is more than a bit weird (there's arguably an excuse for him, but then there's not for the developers). The central mechanic of properly 'setting up' significant story points from the manuscript is actually pretty neat, but it's hamstrung by another central mechanic which isn't explained well, runs contrary to the concept of Wake having to write a coherent story, and leads to a lot of the gameplay feeling like doing the same thing over and over again in a way that isn't particularly interesting.  If you're looking for some more refined Alan Wake gameplay, this is a neat little DLC. If you're looking for a worthy continuation of the story, you might actually want to stay away. Overall, I'll give it a hesitant recommendation; there's a decent game under it all - it's just not Alan Wake.

It is literally like playing a poorly written novel. The women you meet are bimbos, for no reason (an astronomer lady is wearing an open labcoat, with a 'little black dress' under it?!) It feels like it is punishing you for making progress, by throwing waves of cannon fodder at you (the spiders are there exclusively as bullet sponges) The narrative is poor compared to the original, enemies despawn while you're backing away from them, the game is combat focused rather than suspense focused as per the original; enemies spawn behind you for jump scares. And any survival aspect of ammo conservation is also gone, as there are infinite ammo boxes scattered liberally about every level. The weapon-unlock boxes you find smack of artificial longevity by forcing replays to get better weapons.
